conclusion: Two sliders A and B with equal mass m are connected by a light rope and placed on an inclined plane at angle θ = 37°.
A horizontal force F is applied to slider B.
The system is 'just on the verge of not sliding upwards'.
The coefficient of kinetic and static friction μ = 0.5.
Slider A is positioned lower on the incline than slider B.
Slider B is positioned higher on the incline and has a force F applied horizontally to the right.

premise: Forces on Slider A: Weight (mg) acting downward, Normal force (NA) perpendicular to the incline, Friction force (fA) acting down the incline, Tension (T) in the rope pulling upward along the incline.
conclusion: Weight parallel to incline for A: mg·sin(37°) = 0.6mg (down the incline).

premise: Weight perpendicular to incline for A: mg·cos(37°) = 0.8mg (into the incline).
conclusion: Normal force for A: NA = 0.8mg (perpendicular to incline).
Friction force for A: fA = μ·NA = 0.5 × 0.8mg = 0.4mg (up the incline).

premise: Forces on Slider B: Weight (mg) acting downward, Normal force (NB) perpendicular to the incline, Friction force (fB) acting down the incline, Horizontal force F, Tension (T') in the rope (equal to T from slider A).
conclusion: Weight parallel to incline for B: mg·sin(37°) = 0.6mg (down the incline).

premise: Weight perpendicular to incline for B: mg·cos(37°) = 0.8mg (into the incline).
conclusion: Normal force for B: NB = 0.8mg (perpendicular to incline).
Friction force for B: fB = μ·NB = 0.5 × 0.8mg = 0.4mg (up the incline).

premise: Force F has components: Parallel to incline: F·cos(37°) = 0.8F (up the incline), Perpendicular to incline: F·sin(37°) = 0.6F (into the incline).
conclusion: Parallel component of force F: 0.8F (up the incline).
